summary: toxicity of ionizing irradiation is caused by total- or partial-body exposure to a high dose of penetrating ionizing radiation over a short period of time. in clinical medicine, ARS often exists as the adverse side-effect of radiation therapy for cancer and other diseases. administration of medicine for radiation damage control is one of the most effective and direct approaches to protect and treat the injuries caused by ionizing radiation. toll-like receptor 5 (TLR5) plays a pivotal role in the natural immune system. it is expressed in epithelial cells, mononuclear cells, macrophages and dendritic cells. it mediates immune response and inflammation formation, and activates downstream NF-B signaling pathways. the high-density ionic charge of PEI activates the hTLR5 receptor-mediated NF-B pathway, and provides an anti-radiation effect. there have been no reports published investigating the protective effects of PEI against radiation injury. d goat anti-mouse IgG, goat anti-rabbit IgG, MTT cell proliferation and cytotoxicity detection kit, and dual luciferase assay kit were purchased from beyotime Institute of Biotechnology. PEI (0.2–1.0 mol/l) can activate the NF-B intracellular signaling pathway. without radiation, C57BL/6J mice received an intra-peritoneal injection of 70 mg/kg PEI causing no sign of stress or body weight loss. animal survival rate was higher in mice that received a high dose of PEI (9.1 1.8), but lower for the low dose PEI group (6.7 2.2, P 0.001) animal body weight in IR mock declined with time. the correlation coefficient (r) is 0.42 (P 0.02), 0.72 (P 0.0001) and 0.95 (P 0.0001). results demonstrate that PEI has radiation protective activity in an animal model when administered prophylactically. branched PEI can activate the hTLR5-mediated NF-kB signaling pathway in a dose-dependent manner in a cell model. this finding is in agreement with a previous study using linear PEI that activated murine TLR5-mediated NF-B signaling pathway in a separate study. the 50% and 36% mortality rates in low- and high-dose PEI groups are most likely due to insufficient radiation protection provided by the dose of PEI administrated. the dose might have been too low to provide complete radiation protection. polyethylenimine is a new human TLR5 agonist with potential application in radiation protection.
